ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Important concepts and skills of special and general relativity and how to use them to solve real-world problems.
Most of Special Relativity and a good introduction to general relativity. The AP French book on SR, and most of the Schutz book on GR.

A good introduction to relativity, both special and general. For SR, we learned about time dilation, length contraction, and other relativistic phenomena as well as how to read spacetime diagrams. For GR, we looked at a few different solutions to Einstein's equation, including for a black hole.
This course offers a comprehensive introduction to special and general relativity, as well as fluency with tensors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The instructor may offer more materials like lecture notes to aid students' learning.

Strengths: Lectures were very engaging and the professor is a kind and very charismatic person.  The problem sets and exams are not too hard. 

Weaknesses: Not many, though I will say that the professor could have been more careful with notation in the first half of the semester. Far too many u's and v's, and gammas that were sometimes functions of u and sometimes of v, that kept getting mixed up. The problem sets could also occasionally be confusing it that it was not very clear what was being asked.

The content was very cool, though lectures could sometimes be confusing. To be fair, that kinda comes with the territory. It might be nice to follow a textbook more closely for the first half of the course, as I often had to skim through multiple different SR references to keep up.

This course benefitted from clear organization and an engaging lecture style. If I had to suggest improvements, they would be a 30-second overview at the top of each class outlining what we will cover and perhaps soliciting questions a little more. Often it felt like not immediately asking questions in breaks was interpreted as understanding the material, but I think it was often the case that people were simply finishing writing notes or trying to think of what question to ask.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I am a math major who took this course to fulfill the requirements of the B.S. in mathematics, without having taken any other physics classes at Yale (or any other physics since my algebra-based classical mechanics course in early high school). Speaking only from that very specific perspective, this course is excellent. The course is rigorous and approaches the subject from a very mathematical perspective, which I enjoyed (for example, setting c=1 in the first lecture and never looking back). The problem sets are overall fairly light (most took me less than 4 hours, and in the latter half of the semester, a lot took less than 2 or 3). Special relativity is an extremely intuitive and fascinating subject, which doesn't require much in terms of physics prerequisites as long as you're willing to learn and expose yourself to something new. You will accidentally also learn a lot about riemannian metrics and Einstein notation (which is an INCREDIBLE invention that physicists made up so they would never have to do linear algebra) along the way, as well.  Skiba is a wonderful instructor and I think this course is one of the best options for fulfilling the B.S. requirements.

I'd recommend to anyone who's curious about relativity and has somewhat of a background in linear algebra. We didn't use a ton of linear in the course (a little bit in SR), but I think it's conceptually helpful for working with tensors in GR.
Absolutely! Prof. Skiba is a great instructor and is clearly passionate about the material, which is interesting.
